epigraph.p: Fies nobelium tu quoque fontium. —HOR. Fies … HOR. A quotation from Ode 13 of Book 3 of Horace’s Odes, To the Bandusian Fountain. A mid-century translation renders the line as, Thou shalt be ranked, thou alike, in the number of fountains of story (W. Sewell, The Odes and Epodes of Horace, 1850).

lg.l: I love thee, Avon! Avon. The Ōtākaro river, which runs through Christchurch in the South Island, was named the Avon by settlers in 1848. though thy banks have known
No deed of note; thy wandering course along
No Bard of Avon Bard of Avon. A reference to Shakespeare, although the Avon river was not named for Stratford-on-Avon. hath poured forth in song
Thy tuneful praise; thy modest tide hath flown
For ages on, unheeded and alone.
I love thee for thy English name, but more
Because my countrymen along thy shore
Have made new homes. Therefore not all unknown
Henceforth thy streams shall flow. A little while
Shall see thy wastes grow lovely. Not in vain
Shall England’s sons dwell by thee many a mile.
With verdant meads and fields of waving grain
Thy rough uncultured banks ere long shall smile;

Heaven-pointing spires Spires. The Church of England established the Canterbury colony, and its central settlement of Christchurch, under the auspices of the Canterbury Association. shall beautify thy plain.

l.note: 1853. The Canterbury Province was established by the colonial General Assembly in 1853.
